div1.head: Analysis
div1.p: Initially entitled The Jewel of Ethiopia and published in the November 1913 issue of The Crisis as The People of Peoples and Their Gifts to Men, W. E. B. Du Bois's The Star of Ethiopia was performed in New York in October 1913, in Washington, D.C., in October 1915, in Philadelphia in May 1916, and in Los Angeles in May 1925. The pageant's content differed in each of the four venues. Du Bois included Abraham Lincoln in the 1913 version celebrating the fiftieth anniversary of the Emancipation Proclamation, a production with a cast of 350 that was performed before a combined audience of 14,000; meanwhile, the 1915 version, shown before the Centennial General Conference of the AME Church, stressed "the religious development of the Negro" and featured "the twelve apostles of Negro Christianity." Du Bois believed that with The Star of Ethiopia, the "great fact has been demonstrated that pageantry among colored people is . . . of unsurpassed beauty and can be made a means of uplift and education and the beginning of folk drama." Without question, the primary motive was pedagogic. In the pageant, as well as in The Crisis and his 1915 historical study The Negro, Du Bois sought to provide African Americans with a long and continuous history of which they could be proud. The Star of Ethiopia linked the origins of human civilization, the achievements of ancient Egypt, and the greatness of more recent African empires to the experiences of U.S. Blacks.
